message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cellular changes consistent with invasive carcinoma include loss of E-cadherin, which is a protein involved in cell-to-cell adhesion and is often reduced in cancer cells. Intact basement membrane is present in benign tumors but is disrupted in invasive carcinoma. Seeding via capillaries refers to metastasis, which is not present in this case. Increased proliferation of cells with preservation of size and shape is seen in benign tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question is asking for the cellular changes consistent with invasive carcinoma, and among the options, only loss of E-cadherin is associated with invasion and malignancy. Intact basement membrane, seeding via capillaries, and increased proliferation of cells with preservation of size and shape are not specific to invasive carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is associated with invasive and metastatic carcinoma. Intact basement membrane and preservation of cell size and shape are features of benign neoplasms. Seeding via capillaries is a feature of metastasis, but the question states that there are no metastases. Elevated CA-125 levels can indicate ovarian cancer, but do not provide information on cellular changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin indicates a loss of cell-to-cell adhesion, a feature of invasive carcinoma, which is consistent with the diagnosis of ovarian cancer in this case. A intact basement membrane is associated with benign tumors, seeding via capillaries is associated with metastasis and increased proliferation of cells with preservation of size and shape is associated with benign tumors.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is a common feature seen in invasive carcinomas, including ovarian cancer. Intact basement membrane suggests a benign tumor or a carcinoma in situ. Seeding via capillaries and increased proliferation with preservation of size and shape are not specific to this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is associated with invasiveness, and ovarian cancer often presents at advanced stages due to late diagnosis. Intact basement membrane, seeding via capillaries, and increased proliferation of cells with preservation of size and shape are not specific to ovarian cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is a characteristic feature of invasive carcinoma, which is consistent with the diagnosis in this case. The intact basement membrane is generally seen in benign tumors or in situ carcinomas. Seeding via capillaries and increased proliferation of cells with preservation of size and shape are not specific to ovarian cancer or invasive carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is a hallmark of invasive carcinoma and is consistent with the diagnosis of ovarian cancer. Options A, C, and D are not specific to invasive carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Invasive carcinoma is characterized by loss of E-cadherin, which is responsible for cell-cell adhesion and helps to maintain the epithelial phenotype. The other options are not consistent with this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Loss of E-cadherin is a characteristic change in invasive ovarian carcinoma. A intact basement membrane means that the cancer has not spread beyond the epithelial tissue, and seeding via capillaries suggests metastasis. Increased proliferation of cells without preservation of size and shape is a characteristic of a poorly differentiated tumor.
